Jeziel Dener Damasceno

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/1756336793806376
  • Última atualização do currículo em 01/08/2019

Atualmente é Marie Skłodowska-Curie Research Fellow, no Institute of Infection, Immunity & Inflammation / Wellcome Centre for Integrative Parasitology, da Universidade de Glasgow. Possui Bacharelado em Bioquímica pela Universidade Federal de Viçosa (2003-2007). Fez Doutorado Direto em Biologia Celular e Molecular pela Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto - FMRP/USP (2007-2013), com período de estágio 'sandwich' na Universidade de Yale (2012-2012). Concluiu estágios de Pós-Doutorado pelo Departamento de Biologia Celular e Molecular e Bioagentes Patogênicos na Faculdade de Medicina de Ribeirão Preto-FMRP/USP (2013-2014 e 2015-2107). Também fez Pós-Doutorado 'sandwich' no Institute of Infection, Immunity & Inflammation / Wellcome Centre for Integrative Parasitology da Universidade de Glasgow (2014-2015). Tem experiência em Bioquímica, Biologia Celular, Biologia Molecular e Parasitologia, com ênfase nos mecanismos de manutenção do genoma de tripanossomatídeos, tais como as vias de sinalização de danos de DNA, reparo de DNA, replicação de DNA e controle do ciclo celular. (Texto informado pelo autor)

Projetos de pesquisa
2019 - Atual
UK:Brazil Joint Centre Partnership in leishmaniasis
Descrição: UK:Brazil Joint Centre Partnership in leishmaniasis: Centro colaborativo de Pesquisa em leishmaniose entre Universidade de Glasgow, Universidade de York e Universidade de São Paulo. "Does signalling DNA replication stress drive genome diversity in Leishmania?" (University of Glasgow / FMRP_USP - Richard McCulloch / Luiz R. O. Tosi / Jeziel D. Damasceno). The genome of Leishmania displays remarkable plasticity. One facet of such plasticity is potentially genome-wide gene copy number variation, due to both gene expansion and contraction within chromosomes and through stochastic generation of linear and circular extra-chromosomal episomes. Another route for plasticity has been termed mosaic aneuploidy, where different chromosomes display deviations from disomy during growth and in different Leishmania species and isolates. Plasticity has been associated with the acquisition of drug resistance and with host adaptation, though may also act to determine Leishmania species and strain diversity, such as differing leishmaniases disease spectrums. Though recent work has implicated homologous recombination factors in the generation or maintenance of episomes, how other forms of plasticity arise and are tolerated, including whether they share pathways, is less clear. Here, we wish to ask if intrinsic replication ?stress? faced by Leishmania during genome duplication may underlie genome plasticity and diversity. We wish to fully explore the potential roles of factors that modulate replication stress in Leishmania, including whether these control or direct genome plasticity in. We suggest ATR is attractive not simply because it will provide insight into how Leishmania genome plasticity is linked to cell cycle progression, damage signalling and parasite diversity, but because the PK, like related PI3 kinases, is increasingly a target for anti-cancer compounds, which could be repurposed (or form the basis for) new anti-leishmaniases therapies. To ask if the Leishmania stress response is conserved or diverged, we wish to identify the factors that act in conjunction or independently of ATR in the parasite..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Jeziel Dener Damasceno - Integrante / Luiz Ricardo Orsini Tosi - Integrante / Jeremy C. Mottram - Coordenador / Richard McCulloch - Integrante / Angela Kaysel Cruz - Integrante / Paul Denny - Integrante / Hiro Goto - Integrante / Ana P. C. Lima - Integrante / Carlos Costa - Integrante / Daniel Jeffares - Integrante / Paul Key - Integrante / Pegine Walrad - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Medical Research Council - London - Cooperação / Newton Fund UK - Cooperação / Fundação de Amparo à Pesquisa do Estado de São Paulo - Cooperação.
2019 - Atual
Identification of the Replication Fork Proteome in Leishmania
Descrição: The DNA replication process has evolved to guarantee one round of genome duplication per cell cycle, transmitting one copy of the genome to each daughter cell. Gene and chromosome copy number variation (CNV and CCNV) are hallmarks of genome instability that are normally detrimental to survival, including being seen frequently in cancer. Unusually, Leishmania ssp have a remarkably plastic genome, where stochastic, genome-wide rearrangements lead to well tolerated CNV and CCNV. Evidence is mounting that such plasticity is an adaptive strategy, including for drug resistance, hampering the efficiency of anti-Leishmaniasis therapies. Plasticity indicates the existence of peculiar genome maintenance mechanisms, allowing the generation and transmission of malleable genomes. In order to uncover the poorly understood strategies underlying the pervasive genome plasticity in Leishmania ssp, I want to identify its replication machinery components under both normal and replication-stressed conditions. For this, I intend to use iPOND, an approach comprising specific recovery of replication fork associated proteins and identifying them by mass spectrometry. This study will allow me to determine both the conserved and divergent set of factors involved in genome replication in Leishmania ssp, yielding a rich dataset to characterize the molecular and cellular pathways underlying pervasive genome plasticity in Leishmania ssp..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Jeziel Dener Damasceno - Coordenador / Richard McCulloch - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Wellcome - Institutional Strategic Support Fund - Auxílio financeiro.
2017 - Atual
Recombination-derived replication in the eukaryotic microbe Leishmania: a genome-wide process?(RECREPEMLE)
Descrição: In any organism, the need to reproduce is paramount, with genome replication being the earliest step in the process. The machinery and mechanisms of DNA replication are widely conserved, with initiation occurring at defined bi-directional DNA synthesis sites termed origins. Though origins may not be conserved DNA sequences, they are defined through binding conserved replication initiator factors. In some circumstances, such as after DNA damage or origin deletion, origin-independent replication can be observed in cellular organisms and can be driven by recombination. However, origin-independent replication is not normally considered to be a genome-wide, central reaction of genome replication. Very recently, genome-wide mapping of DNA replication initiation in two species of the kinetoplastid parasite Leishmania revealed only a single locus-specific origin per chromosome. Analyses of Leishmania S phase length and DNA synthesis speed suggest that a single origin-based strategy is insufficient for complete genome duplication, indicating replication in these eukaryotic microbes relies on origin-independent initiation to support origin-directed initiation. In this proposal, I will test the hypothesis that stochastic origin-independent DNA synthesis initiation events occur throughout the Leishmania genome due to homologous recombination acting on DNA lesions. If correct, this work will reveal the first example of a cellular organism that uses origin-independent replication as a core feature of genome duplication. The genome-wide use of recombination-driven replication would alter our view of DNA replication evolution and would explain the remarkable genome plasticity of Leishmania, with implications for how the parasite adapts genome structure and gene expression in the face of changing environments. Such adaptive change is seen during acquisition of resistance to anti-leishmanial drugs, and so this work will provide insight into the use and development of therapies..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

Integrantes: Jeziel Dener Damasceno - Coordenador / Richard McCulloch - Integrante.
Financiador(es): Marie Skłodowska-Curie Actions - European Comission - Auxílio financeiro.
